This government is restoring balance and integrity to our immigration program. Our goal is to make life as easy as possible for those who make Australia their new home. Our measures are consistent with taking responsibility for not only the future of those immigrants who have settled here, but also the new arrivals. If this is being discriminatory, as the opposition so loudly proclaims, then I suggest that their concerns are more for votes than the wellbeing of this country.

Our priority lies with the reunion of migrants entering as the spouses or children of Australians. Parents, brothers, sisters, aunts and uncles can apply on their own merits and if they qualify, will be welcomed. By introducing a two‐year waiting period for social security benefits for migrants, we have redirected a substantial amount of welfare dollars into the community.

BREAK.PARA: It must be noted that this government has a commitment to skilled and business migrants who, we all know, benefit the economy and create jobs for Australians. Those of my constituents who look closely at this government's employment program will see that we are not focussing on shuffling funds by moving people off the dole onto the endless and often pointless training schemes. This was the cycle for the unemployed as established by the Keating government: off the dole to reduce the figures; onto a training scheme with a marginal chance of a job at the end, and then back on the dole.

A young man who came to my electorate office to have his CV photocopied had done six courses during the year, including a six weeks course in panel beating. I ask this House: who would allow a person with just six weeks training to start knocking dents out of their car? I am not alone when I say that I get many calls from constituents complaining that they have a job available but cannot find anyone with enough basic skills.

A local builder told me two weeks ago that he had more work than he could handle and desperately needed to hire another three carpenters. He said any good carpenter was as busy as he was. He was now having to knock back work because he could not find anyone experienced enough to hire.

This brings us to the $265 million in this budget set aside for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships for the next year. Employers cannot afford to train young people without assistance. This bill introduces a $1,500 completion payment for employers whose apprentice or trainee achieves Australian qualification framework level 3 competency. In other words, we are training young people in jobs.

Then there is the work for the dole pilot scheme, with funding of $21 million. This is not a shuffle off the dole scheme; this is giving people on the dole the most important thing they can achieve—that is, a work ethic—while placing them with a team to work at a real job, one that is of value to the community and therefore of value to the participant.I do not need to remind anyone of the demoralising effect of being unemployed. This can lead to the belief that you are unemployable. We can and will turn this around with our school to work strategy which has already been piloted in Queensland with great success.

We also have introduced our Green Corps program, which creates training for people in one of the most important areas—the environment. People joining the Green Corps are working alongside environmental specialists and learning skills that are vital not only to the future of this planet and our nation but vital to the immediate community in which they live.

I remind the House of the $1.25 billion in this budget to fund the Natural Heritage Trust over six years. The government was opposed tooth and nail by the opposition and minor parties in establishing this fund—the largest restoration program for our environment. Besides its vital importance to restoring our rivers, vegetation and land, this massive injection of funds will create employment. This bill makes it clear that this government is establishing the environment for jobs and training for young people from the moment they leave school, not after they have spent years losing confidence as they queue for the dole.

The opposition and many politically motivated groups in the community are demanding faster action in creating jobs. This government will not create illusory jobs. This government is establishing a sound foundation for industry to create jobs—real jobs with lasting benefits. If the previous government looks at its own track record in my electorate of Griffith, there is a major area where jobs could have been created but this has been ignored.

I take you back to when the federal government, in consultation with the state and local government in Brisbane, set about upgrading Brisbane Airport and the Brisbane port. The port, at great expense, was moved to the mouth of the river at Fisherman's Island. The federal government committed funds to these two major projects, as well as funding for a national gauge rail line running from Acacia Ridge to the port. This was completed in November 1994. This grand plan was known as the gateway strategic plan, an initiative by the then Liberal Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson. This was a plan for industry along the Brisbane River from Colmslie to Moreton Bay.

The region along the northern corner of my electorate is well‐positioned to take advantage of this strategy and we looked to receive major investment from the commercial and industry sectors. Industry would create not only construction jobs but long‐term employment. After exhaustive public consultation a regional strategic plan known as SEQ 2001 was evolved, which included the gateway strategic plan.

I point out all of this because it shows just how much work and planning went into creating the infrastructure to encourage industry in the suburbs of Colmslie, Cannon Hill, Murarrie and Gibson Island, all of which are in my electorate. This strategic plan has gone into stagnation. I look at the rail line, the port, the airport and the arterial road, and ask the same question as my constituents: what happened to the promised jobs? I can tell them what happened at least to the last 200 which were promised by BHP. Last year the Brisbane City Council refused approval for BHP to establish a $160 million steel plant right in the heart of the area earmarked for such industry. I investigated the project. It fulfilled all criteria. It was knocked back purely for political expediency—and with it went 200 construction jobs and over 70 permanent jobs.

With signals like that from Labor's Brisbane City Council, it is no wonder industries pack up and leave Australia, taking their jobs with them. This government has shown, with its first and now with its second budget, that we pay our bills before we throw taxpayers' money around for political gain. The changes created by this budget are establishing a sound foundation for Australia to redirect its focus on work opportunities, to retrain young school leavers and to pave the way for employers to hire apprentices. This training is for jobs which exist. We are creating an environment for savings as this budget establishes for the first time a savings plan for all Australians.

It is very easy to swing a cudgel to make holes in the budget strategy as laid down by this government, but the facts and figures are there. This government has stopped the endless flow of dollars from the pockets of Australians. By the end of this next term, John Howard will have put this country back in the black. But it is more than dollars in the bank—this government has a social policy to match. We are changing the attitudes of two generations brought up to believe that the government was an employer.

We have set in motion aged care reforms to tackle the urgent, if not critical, need for reform in the nursing home sector. The opposition can rant and rave about the introduction of accommodation bonds, but they cannot alter the fact that the nursing home sector is in crisis. The Labor Party cannot deny that our senior citizens, who are in need of special care, have been ignored. The Labor Party cannot deny that our nursing homes are having trouble keeping afloat and that many are unable to provide adequate care and facilities for their residents.

The Labor Party argues that we are not putting enough money into the nursing home sector. Funny about that; it had been busy taking it out. The Keating government reduced capital funding to nursing homes from $200 million in 1989‐90 to just over $10 million in its last year. We have not only introduced accommodation bonds as a capital funding program for nursing homes, but also increased the government subsidy for dementia care by 30 per cent.

We have redirected funding for child‐care assistance to increase the number of low‐income families able to qualify for assistance from 19,000 to 51,000. There has been relative silence from the opposition on this budget reform, but I am not surprised. Under the previous government, non‐working parents were receiving 50 hours of taxpayer funded child care per week. This has been reduced to 20 hours. We have acknowledged that non‐working parents who are studying or looking for work do need child‐care assistance, maybe for up to 50 hours a week, and we have also increased assistance for those using outside school hours care. This is a government which has produced a budget for economic and social growth, and I support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997-98, the 1997‐98 budget, together with the estimates for the coming years. I would like to congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) for putting together a document that not only meets the requirements of our nation today but, more importantly, meets the requirements of our nation in the period leading up to the next millennium.

SPEECH.PARA: This budget is clearly focused on improving Australia's savings record. It is clearly focused on providing a stable economy in which business can grow and in which business can develop. Up until now there has been a growing tendency in government budgets to focus on issues that seem to please the electorate as opposed to budgets that focus on issues that are good for the electorate. There is a fundamental difference, of course. It is easy to envisage the Treasurer coming down the flagpole of Parliament House every budget with a bag full of goodies like Santa Claus and delivering a lot of goodies to people in the electorates and to businesses.

I will remind the House that North Sydney, in my electorate, is the third largest business district in Australia. I discussed the budget with some of the 36,000 small businesses in my electorate, which is a very large figure, and with many of my 125,000 constituents. I encountered a disappointing response in all those discussions and that was, `What's in it for me? What do I get out of the budget?'. I have called it the Santa Claus phenomenon. Santa Claus comes twice each year to the Australian people—once on 25 December and again when the federal budget is announced.

We have to change that attitude. It is a very difficult change to incorporate into the Australian ethos. It is very difficult. It is difficult when you have the New South Wales Carr government promising to give the parents of every school kid a cheque for $50 at the beginning of the school year just because the kid turns up to school. It does not matter whether they go to Newington or whether they go to Mount Druitt High, they get a cheque for $50. It is classic middle class welfare.

Even worse, the Keating government introduced the pregnancy benefit, if you like. Every woman who had a baby was to receive a cheque in the mail for $200, and that was meant to ease the pain. It was not means tested so, in effect, it was a new form of middle class welfare. My response to that is that we cannot have middle class welfare at a time when we are trying to change the attitude in Australia so that people must rely on themselves for their future and save for their future.

BREAK.PARA: Too few Australians would be aware that every week 7.5 million Australians expect a Department of Social Security cheque. That includes age pensioners who are, of course, in many cases, deserving of their age pension. That is 1.673 million people. In addition to that there is family tax payment; farm household allowance; mature age allowance; mature age partner allowance; Newstart allowance; Newstart mature age allowance; parenting allowance; partner allowance; rehabilitation pension; sickness allowance; sole parent pension; special benefit; widow allowance; widow's pension; wife pension; youth training allowance; bereavement allowance; carer pension; child disability allowance; disability support pension; disability wage supplement; disadvantaged persons scheme; double orphan pension, and so on.

When is it going to stop? When will people stop expecting that they are going to get some form of benefit? There are 7.5 million Australians who expect a Department of Social Security cheque. Not for one second would I deny those who need help a helping hand, not for one minute, not for a second, because if people deserve then they deserve it. But 7.5 million Australians are not deserving of Department of Social Security support.

There are 7.2 million Australians that are paying taxation and of the total budget of $133 billion, $53.4 billion is spent on welfare. Over 40 per cent of the budget is spent on welfare—health, $20.7 billion; education, $11 billion; defence, $10.4 billion; economic services, and that incorporates repayment of our national debt, $8.3 billion; general services covering administrative services and a range of functions in support of the other areas, $6 billion; and of course payments to the states, $17 billion. That payment to the states is supplemented by the states' own taxation system, which roughly accounts for $33 billion around Australia.
So the total tax take around Australia is around $150 billion, of which one‐third goes in welfare to 7.5 million Australians.

I suppose what I am trying to say to the people in my electorate is that we should support the people that need a helping hand. That is, part of the most basic Liberal phenomena and theme in the 1990s has to be to support people that deserve a helping hand.

In my electorate, there are people that can afford and are prepared to pay their way in the 1990s and in the years beyond. It is those sort of people that are starting to come to terms with the fact that we cannot expect to get middle class welfare. We cannot expect to get a whole range of schemes that are going to prop up business.

I have got a simple message, particularly for big business and it is this. As soon as you start to develop a welfare mentality, we can almost give up the game, because you are meant to be the proponents of self sufficiency, you are meant to pride yourselves on making a buck, earning that buck, producing a buck and then making a profit out of it. If you start to cry out for business welfare then you are letting the side down and you are making yourselves not only nationally uncompetitive but more importantly internationally uncompetitive. It is that part of business welfare when you see significant business interest groups in the Sydney Morning Herald, in the Australian or in the Financial Review saying, `What is in the budget for me? What did I get out of it'?

I will tell you what you got out of it. You got something out of it that you never got in the late 1980s or in the early 1990s under the Labor party. You are getting a long‐term stable economy. And what does that mean? That means low inflation, that means low interest rates and lower interest rates and it also means most importantly that you have got an economy that is starting to grow and to improve its exportation particularly to the biggest consumer markets and the fastest growing consumer markets in Asia.

In short, what does that mean for business? Businesses went through a very volatile period under the Labor Party in the late 1980s and early 1990s. They were sold a pup during the 1980s that a boom would continue forever. The Labor Party sold it. You saw Bob Hawke and Paul Keating arm in arm with the Alan Bonds and the Christopher Skases and the Russell Gowards and all the various players that were out there—the entrepreneurial godfathers of the Australian economy, arm in arm. And what happened? Those people that they were shaking hands with and being photographed with in their black tie suits went to the wall quite dramatically. We are still feeling the effects of that.

The most serious effect of that was not the October 1987 crash. The most serious effect was not the movement of money out of equities into real estate. The most significant effect was that it blew the confidence of small business in Australia.

We came into the 1990s following the credit squeeze instituted by Paul Keating when he was treasurer. We came into an environment with fairly high inflation, but the government was trying to rescue the economy and failing miserably with the net result that again small business seemed to suffer the brunt through high interest rates, uncompetitive inflation levels and significantly falling consumer confidence.
The most significant table, which I seek leave to incorporate into my speech, is table E1 in the Commonwealth budget papers.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows—
Table E1:Commonwealth Budget Sector Revenue, Underlying Outlays and Underlying Balance 1960-61 to 2000-01

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the most revealing table in the entire budget because it gives a total breakdown of the underlying balance of the Commonwealth from 1960‐61 to 2000‐2001. And lo and behold, this extremely revealing document seems also to indicate the ebb and flow of the political fluctuations in Australia. What we saw throughout the 1960s was an underlying balance of a surplus between one and nearly four per cent of GDP.

BREAK.PARA: In the mid‐1970s, the underlying balance suddenly went into a deficit. Suddenly, we were running deficits of around minus two per cent of GDP and, of course, that was the effect of the Whitlam expenditure years when, basically, underlying outlays jumped around five per cent of GDP and he increased expenditure by 25 per cent in three years. And we start to wonder why we still have not recovered from the Whitlam years. Of course, revenue did not follow it and Australia went into significant deficit.

In the early 1980s, we managed to recover. We started to have a couple of surpluses but with the recession in the mid‐1980s, we went back into a deficit and, of course, as revenue was booming in the late 1980s we went into a surplus again. That was primarily linked to the massive creation of false capital in the Australian economy and, of course, in the late 1980s and early 1990s Australia once again went into a deficit as a part of GDP and we have not actually recovered. In fact, this year the deficit will be around minus 1.3 per cent and in 1997‐98, it will be 0.7 per cent. It will not be until 1998‐99 that we will actually achieve a balance for the first time since 1990.

What does this mean for business? Over the next few years we are going to try and create a stable environment for you to do business. There is no doubt that interest rates have to come down further. When small businesses are paying 9.5 per cent and we have an inflation rate of 1.5 per cent, you start to really recognise why they are not making the super profits that everyone expected. You start to really recognise why they are not employing more people because within our taxation system there are significant disincentives for people to employ other people because of payroll tax, the superannuation guarantee levy, and a whole range of other factors that make the oncosts of employing someone far too great for a business to cope with.

So how do you get business to employ more people? How do you get business to start to generate its own expansion? It is simple: you start to make businesses profitable, and that is a partnership between the economy and the businessmen or the businesswomen themselves. In the first place, this budget focuses on the economy. It is saying that we want to give you the right indicators and the right environment so that you can start to take a calculated risk to expand your business. You are not going to have rapid increases in interest rates. We are going to start to give you lower interest rates for the longer term. The best indication of how successful we have been in this is the significant narrowing of the gap between the 10‐year bonds of the US and the Australian 10‐year bond benchmark to just under 60 basis points. That is the narrowest difference between the US 10‐year bond and the Australian 10‐year bond for many years.

What does that mean? It means that international investors are starting to gain confidence in Australia. When they start to price our 10‐year bonds at the same level, or close to the same level, as the US 10‐year bonds, they are saying, `Listen, Australia is actually a stable and growing economy to invest in and we have confidence in Australia.'

What does that mean? The Governor of the Reserve Bank expressed it perfectly when he appeared before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration. He said that there is growing confidence in the Australian economy and that at no time in Australia's history have home loans been more affordable or more accessible to the Australian people. That was a very significant comment. More importantly than that, the Governor of the Reserve Bank said that we have to get increased competition into small business lending.

At the end of the day, banks are there to make a profit for their shareholders. We must recognise that. The banks' profit comes about through their making one loan, managed by three people, of $500 million to a major corporate customer, rather than making a multitude of small loans to small businesses—500 loans at $1 million each or 1,000 loans at $500,000 each—because the resources going into the cost of managing the loans and the possibility of business failure is far more significant with small business than it is with big business.

Therefore, the banks will lend to a big business every day because it is easier and cheaper to manage than it is to lend to a small business. How do we create competition in that environment? Banks have to play their part, but we also need to look to other means. One of the Wallis inquiry recommendations—which I will not go into today—was that we should be looking at trying to improve competition in the banking sector in the provision of lending, particularly to small business.

There is little doubt that through this budget we are providing the stable economy that Australians have been yearning for. We are concerned—and we should be concerned—about wage growth. We should be concerned that there is not an outbreak of wage demands, that people are not going beyond the pale in terms of negotiating increases in salary over the next two to three years.

I am very concerned about recent claims that Commonwealth Bank employees are looking to increase their remuneration by around seven per cent per annum. If that happens, rest assured that Australian businesses will suffer the pain. Even if it is offset by productivity improvements, the people who are going to suffer are the businesses that cannot make the profit to pay the salaries.

There is only one way, in a low inflation environment, that they can meet the expectations of, essentially, their shareholders, and that is to start improving productivity to perhaps unreasonable levels. You can only do that by improving your equipment, looking for new markets and working out better industrial relations, or simply by retrenching people and getting people to work longer hours. Maybe that is one of the reasons why we had a very disappointing jobs outcome in the last month. Australian business needs to stop focusing on reducing its employment levels. It needs to focus on how it can become more profitable and, therefore, employ more people.

I commend the bill to the House. It is a landmark bill. It puts in train the budget until the next millennium. It puts in train the basis upon which we are going to build a stable economy for Australian business. More importantly, we are building an environment in which the Australian people can continue to have confidence that we as a government are acting on behalf of all Australians, particularly Howard's battlers. They are the big beneficiaries of this budget through the various announcements that have come to pass. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aircraft Landing Systems

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 4 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to new technologies in the field of aircraft landing systems which would allow the take‐off and landing of aircraft to occur unrestricted by poor weather conditions creating low visibility; if not, will he undertake to acquaint himself with these developments.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the aircraft autopilot system known as Compressed Heuristic Universal Reaction Planners (CHURPs) being developed by Dr D Stirling, a BHP senior research scientist, which negates fog and other poor weather conditions as major impediments to the take‐off and landing of aircraft.
(3) Will the Minister aid or assist Dr Stirling in developing CHURPs for the benefit of Australian and international air transport; if not, why not.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to the benefits associated with the Microwave Landing System (MLS) in overcoming poor weather conditions and low visibility for aircraft take‐offs and landings; if so (a) what are the benefits and (b) is the Commonwealth considering a changeover of Australian airports at Australian airports from the Instrument Landing System (ILS) to MLS; if not, why not.

(5) Has his attention been drawn to the benefits associated with the Differential Global‐Positioning System (DGPS) in overcoming poor weather conditions and low visibility for aircraft take‐offs and landings; if so, (a) what are the benefits and (b) is the Commonwealth considering a changeover from the Instrument Landing System (ILS) to DGPS; if not, why not.
(6) Have studies been carried out which have recorded how many days a year, on average, an airport situated at Goulburn, NSW, would be affected by fog; if so, how many.

(7) Is he able to say how many days a year, on average, the (a) Denver, (b) O'Hare, (c) Heathrow, (d) John F Kennedy and (e) Frankfurt international airports are affected by fog and poor weather conditions that would subsequently provide poor visibility for the landing and take‐off of aircraft; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am provided with updates on new technologies in the field of aircraft landing systems by Airservices Australia when there may be a beneficial impact on the management of aircraft take‐offs and landings at Australia airports.

(2) Airservices Australia has advised me that it had no specific knowledge of the Compressed Heuristic Universal Reaction Planners (CHURPs) being developed by Dr D Stirling and a literature search has provided little information on the project. Airservices has advised that it understands that Dr Stirling apparently prepared his PhD thesis on the subject. Airservices are further investigating this matter.

(3) The Transport and Regional Development portfolio does not have funds available to assist research projects such as Dr Stirling's development of CHURPs. Issues of this nature are better addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism.

(4) Airservices Australia has advised me of: (a) the benefits of the Microwave Landing System (MLS) as a standard precision approach, landing and departure guidance system capable of supporting aircraft take‐off and landing in conditions of low visibility. Standards for MLS are published by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO).

(b) MLS has been developed and manufactured in Australia. Currently an MLS is installed and is available to be used at Canberra Airport. Other installations are in service throughout the world. Some of these have been made by an Australian manufacturer.

Australia is following a strategy established by ICAO at a world meeting in 1995. This strategy provides for the retention of the ILS, the installation of MLS when and as required and the evaluation of Differential Global Navigation Satellite System (DGNSS), sometimes called Differential Global Positioning System (DGPS), for approach and landing applications.
A changeover from ILS to MLS is not seen as necessary in Australia and no further MLS installations are planned for Australian airports.

(5) Airservices has advised the Minister that: (a) Current expectations suggest that the DGNSS system will provide greater flexibility in operation and lower cost compared with the existing ILS system.

(b) Australia is evaluating DGNSS (or DGPS) and is actively participating in a technical panel of ICAO in the development of appropriate standards. DGNSS systems have not yet been standardised by ICAO. Australia will pursue the transition from ILS to DGNSS when the DGNSS is operationally proven and financially viable.
(6) The most recent advice from the Bureau of Meteorology, which collects data at Goulburn, indicates that in 1996 there were 32 days of fog in Goulburn.
(7) No. The portfolio collects no data on fog at overseas airports.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Development Employment Projects: Participants

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do participants in Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) (a) pay tax and (b) forego benefits they would have received under unemployment benefits; if so, (i) why, (ii) what are the details, (iii) under what circumstances is tax paid, (iv) how many participants pay tax and (v) what is the total sum paid in tax.
(2) How many CDEP programs exist.
(3) How many CDEP participants are there.
(4) What sums are provided to CDEP (a) programs and (b) participants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following information to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes.

(1) (b) CDEP participants are required to forego their entitlement to Newstart Allowance (NSA) or Youth Training Allowance (YTA) to participate in the scheme. Sole Parent Pensioners (SPP) recipients may also participate in the scheme, but they do not forego their entitlement to the pension. Their pension is reduced under the DSS income test provisions according to the amount of income earned through participation in the CDEP scheme.
(1) (b) (i & ii) CDEP participants are excluded from claiming NSA or YTA under the Commonwealth funded program exclusion provisions of section 532A of the Taxation Act, which states:

"A job search allowance is not payable to a person for a period if the person has received, or may receive, income for that period that is paid by a community or group from funds provided under a Commonwealth funded employment program."
(1) (b) (iii & iv) PAYE tax is deducted from the wages of all CDEP participants by the grantee body (as the employer).
(1) (b) (v) ATSIC has no record of the amount of tax paid by CDEP participants. Tax deductions are made by grantee organisations and remitted direct to the Australian Taxation Office.
(2) As at 1 April 1997, there were 268 CDEP projects, including those administered by the Torres Strait Authority.
(3) As at 1 April 1997, there were 29,764 participants, including those in projects administered by the Torres Strait Authority.

(4) All CDEP funding is provided by ATSIC to grantee organisations. The exact amount paid to participants is not available because participant wage rates are determined by grantee organisations. ATSIC funding conditions require that each participant is given the opportunity to earn at least the equivalent of their former unemployment benefit.
Actual program expenditure by ATSIC for the 1995‐96 financial year was: Wages—$227,529,764; Capital Funding—$32,945,304; Recurrent Funding—$45,883,333;
Operational Planning Funding—$2,569,232.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Unemployment Rates

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

QUESTION.PARA: What were the unemployment rates in the NSW local government areas of (a) Auburn, (b) Holroyd and (c) Parramatta in each month between July and December 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Estimates of the unemployment rates for Local Government Areas are compiled by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs on a quarterly basis. The latest data available are for the June quarter 1996. Unemployment rate estimates for the Local Government Areas of Auburn, Holroyd and Parramatta are as follows:

These estimates are from the DEETYA publication Small Area Labour Markets which provides estimates of the number of unemployed persons and unemployment rates at the Statistical Local Area (SLA) level. (In most instances SLAs are identical to Local Government Areas.) It should be noted that these estimates have been derived using the Structure Preserving Estimation (SPREE) methodology and are based on Department of Social Security (DSS) data on unemployment beneficiaries and Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) labour force survey data. As such, they are not exact and accordingly should be used with caution. The SPREE methodology produces small area labour market estimates that reflect the regional disparities of the DSS data while being consistent with ABS labour force data.

It should also be noted that the data are original and are not, therefore, seasonally adjusted or trended. Original data are subject to greater variability because the effects of normal seasonal variation have not been removed and the effects of other irregular impacts have not been reduced.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Service Delivery Agency

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 6 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the CES and the Department of Social Security to be restructured.

(2) If so, will the (a) St Kilda office of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) in Shakespeare Grove, Vic., cease to exist in its present form and be replaced by a Public Employment Placement Agency, (b) Caulfield CES on the corner of Grange and Glenhuntly Roads be relocated and (c) St Kilda Youth Access Centre be relocated out of St Kilda.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The 1996/97 Budget delivered the most significant reorganisation of labour market assistance arrangements since the establishment of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) fifty years ago. The new arrangements are designed to improve both the efficiency and effectiveness of employment assistance for job seekers who will have access to a service that is more convenient, accessible and tailored to their individual needs.

By March 1998 there will be: an integrated, `one‐stop‐shop', Commonwealth Service Delivery Agency (CSDA) providing income support, basic employment and student assistance services to traditional CES and Department of Social Security (DSS) clients; and a new employment placement market in which employment placement enterprises (EPEs) and a corporatised Public Employment Placement Enterprise (PEPE) will operate in a contestable market to provide employment assistance services to job seekers, particularly disadvantaged job seekers.

(2) The new CSDA will provide support services to all job seekers. The new Agency with over 300 sites across Australia built on the existing DSS Office network, will continue to provide high quality information services to all job seekers. Staff from current DEETYA Student Assistance Centres, Youth Access Centres and around 2000 other CES staff will transfer to the Agency throughout 1997.

The CSDA will be located in the former DSS Caulfield and St Kilda sites. The CSDA will provide a single shopfront where young people will be able to go for assistance including services provided by Youth Access Centres. The new arrangements will enable servicing of young people to be approached with a clearer emphasis on education and training assistance. Early intervention and the provision of information on available options and careers will also be an important part of these arrangements. The rationale for this focus is that without appropriate skills or education levels, young people will have difficulty in getting out of the unemployment cycle and are less likely to gain long term employment. The St Kilda Youth Access Centre will be relocated with integrated youth services at the CSDA in St Kilda.

The new PEPE will compete alongside private and community providers in the new employment placement market to provide intensive support services to disadvantaged job seekers, job brokerage services to job ready clients, job search assistance to job seekers and other support services to employers of apprentices/trainees and job seekers seeking self employment opportunities. The size, organisational and locational arrangements for the PEPE will depend on its market share, and in particular the extent, mix and spread of the business it is contracted to provide. Its role as provider of last resort or provider of community service obligations will also impact on its locations/sites. Once the market shares are decided by DEETYA, following the tender round in the period June‐ December 1997, PEPE management will decide the numbers and locations of staff required by the PEPE to effectively deliver its services. In determining its likely sites, the PEPE will draw on the existing CES offices, including the two offices mentioned, namely St Kilda and Caulfield.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Migration Regulations: Long Term Relationships

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he issue a media release on 30 May 1996, describing compelling circumstances as those of a strongly compassionate nature, such as where there are Australian citizen children in the relationship or where the couple have been in a genuine and continuing relationship for at least two years.

(2) Does the definition of "long term relationship" in the Migration Regulations which were amended in November 1996 refer to a relationship between an applicant and another person, each as a spouse of the other, that has continued (a) if there is a dependent child of both the applicant and the other person , for not less than 2 years and (b) in any other case , for not less than 5 years.

(3) Does the amendment apply to persons unlawfully in Australia and in a relationship for at least two years but less than five years and who applied for a visa following his media release of 30 May 1996; if so, why is the definition in the amendment different to that in his media release; if not, under what circumstances does the amendment to the regulations apply.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Persons unlawfully in Australia are usually restricted from making an application for residence while they remain in Australia. My announcement on 30 May 1996 was intended as a concession to allow certain unlawful non‐citizens to apply for residence, while remaining in Australia. It applies where the applicant has a spouse relationship with an Australian citizen or permanent resident and can demonstrate compelling circumstances of the nature described in my media release, which may prevent departure from Australia to apply overseas.

(2) The definition of "long term relationship" relates to waiver provisions within the two‐stage processing of applications for permanent residence on the basis of a spouse relationship or an interdependent relationship with an Australian partner. Applicants for these visas are either persons offshore seeking to migrate or holders of a substantive visa onshore.

(3) No. The definition of "long term relationship" included in the November 1996 regulations amendment does not apply to persons unlawfully in Australia who have applied for a visa following the media release of 30 May 1996.

The definition relates to waiver provisions within the two‐stage processing of spouse and interdependent applications. New processing requirements offshore were introduced in November 1996 which entail two stages. The new procedures require a combined application for a temporary visa and a permanent visa be lodged at the same time and same place. The first stage of processing allows for the grant of a temporary visa to successful applicants, and the second stage, which normally occurs two years after the combined application was made, allows for the grant of a permanent visa to the applicant. The decision maker may waive the requirement that two years must have passed since the combined application was made before deciding the permanent visa application, if, at the time the combined application was made, the applicant was in a "long term relationship" with their Australian partner.

The new processing requirements offshore mirror existing procedures for onshore applications. The definition of "long term relationship" therefore also applies in onshore applications lodged by persons who hold a substantive visa at the time of application for a spouse or interdependent visa.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Disadvantaged Schools Program Funding: Electoral Division of Perth

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: What sum did each (a) primary school and (b) high school in the electoral division of Perth receive under the Disadvantaged Schools Program in 1996 and what sum will each receive in 1997.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Disadvantaged Schools Program (DSP) assisted schools and school community groups in improving the educational participation, learning outcomes and personal development of young people disadvantaged by socio‐economic circumstances.

Under former arrangements the Commonwealth provided DSP funds to government, Catholic and independent school educational authorities. Responsibility for the detailed administration of the program, including the allocation of funds to individual schools rested with these authorities. The allocations to individual schools were based on each authority's stated principles for nominating schools within its sector as disadvantaged and levels of funding were made in accordance with their local priorities and relative needs. Activities were to reflect program objectives and be designed to achieve outcomes for the target group as set out in the relevant National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS) agreements. The DSP ceased in 1996.

In 1997 a new `broadbanding' structure realigning and simplifying the Commonwealth's targeted and quality programs to schools was introduced. As the former DSP had a strong emphasis on developing literacy skills, it was incorporated into the new broadbanded Literacy Program along with the former English as a Second Language‐General Support Program and the 1997 new initiative the National Literacy and Numeracy Strategy. Funding previously marked for DSP can now be used more flexibly by education authorities to best meet the basic learning needs of educationally disadvantaged students. Individual school funding information is not held by the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Drug Education and Prevention Programs: Funding

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say how many persons in each age group in each State and Territory are considered opiate dependent.
(2) Is he also able to say what is the current death rate due to illicit drugs in each age group in each State and Territory.

(3) Further to his answer to part (1) of question No. 1241 (Hansard , 14 May 1997, page 3561), (a) what per capita funding does the Government provide each year under its National Drug Strategy and (b) is he able to say what per capita funding the US Government provides through its equivalent national anti‐drug campaign each year.

(4) Will he discuss with the Prime Minister and the Attorney‐General convening a National Drug Summit featuring State and Territory Health Ministers and Attorneys‐General, police and judicial authorities, experts in the field of drug and heroin dependency, and representatives from social welfare and religious bodies in order to discuss new approaches to obtaining a national solution to the heroin problem; if not, why not.

(5) Has a National Drug Summit or its equivalent, convened by the Federal Government or the Federal Minister for Health, ever been convened; if so, (a) when was it held, (b) what were the major issues discussed and (c) did the summit make major and clear proposals for the direction of the nation's drug strategy.
(6) Is he able to say what is the current rate of (a) HIV and (b) hepatitis C infection among intravenous drug users in each age group in each State and Territory, and is the rate increasing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are a number of difficulties in attempting to estimate the number of opiate dependent people on a national let alone a jurisdictional and age group basis.

Heroin use is illegal and hence users often prefer that others not know about their drug use. There is no universally accepted definition of "regular" or "dependent" heroin use and there are no well tested and unbiased methods available to produce a credible estimate of the number of people who make up such "hidden populations".

The number of people who are registered to receive methadone maintenance treatment in each State and Territory is known and occasional surveys of treatment agencies provide information on the proportion of clients seeking treatment who are opiate users. However, there is currently no reliable way of monitoring the number of opiate dependent people there are in addition to the groups who are in contact with treatment agencies.

The National Drug Strategy Household Survey collects data on lifetime and recent (in the past 12 months) use of heroin. In the 1995 Household Survey the proportion of respondents reporting recent use of heroin was 0.4 per cent. Because of the very small numbers involved, any sub‐analysis of these responses or extrapolation of the results to the general community is of limited value. Furthermore, population surveys are not well suited to estimating the number of heroin users in the community. Household surveys are likely to under‐sample heroin users whose lifestyle makes them less likely to live in conventional living arrangements and less likely to participate in household surveys either because of their unavailability at the time the interviewer calls or their reluctance to agree to be interviewed. Heroin use is also likely to be under‐reported because it is illegal.

As part of the 1995 Review of Methadone Treatment in Australia, the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre (University of New South Wales) used multiple methods (all with a degree of imperfection) to produce a range of estimates of the number of heroin users in Australia. While there were considerable uncertainties in these estimates, the work suggested that in 1990 there were approximately 59,000 regular heroin users.

My department is currently working with the Illicit Drugs Expert Working Group (a subcommittee of the National Drug Strategy Committee) in developing a program of research relating to opiate use, one component of which is expected to be the establishment of baseline data on the number of heroin users in Australia.

(2) There are also difficulties associated with monitoring the number of deaths caused by illicit drugs. The Australian Bureau of Statistics routinely collects data on all deaths in Australia. This data is provided by the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages in each State and Territory and is based on the information provided on death certificates, coded according to the International Classification of Diseases. The codes relevant to deaths caused by illicit drugs are largely those which identify drug dependence and accidental poisoning. This coding system results in some limitations. For example, while deaths due to opiates can be distinguished from those due to amphetamines it is not possible to distinguish deaths related to heroin use from those related to methadone or other opiates. The accuracy of the data is also highly dependent on the accuracy of the information entered on the death certificate.

Because of the limitations of the mortality data, I am not in a position to provide information on the current death rate due to illicit drugs. However, the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre is currently undertaking work on behalf of my department which will analyse available information on opiate‐related deaths on a jurisdictional and age group basis. This work is expected to be completed by July 1997.

(3) (a) It would of course be feasible to express funding under the National Drug Strategy in per capita terms, however such calculations are somewhat meaningless because the National Drug Strategy does not represent the total response to the problems of drug and alcohol misuse, nor does it represent the Commonwealth Government's total contribution. The National Drug Strategy did not replace the existing prevention, treatment and law enforcement programming to deal with drug problems. Large amounts of funds outside of the National Drug Strategy continue to be spent on the treatment of disease and trauma caused by the misuse of drugs, and for law enforcement efforts to restrict the supply of drugs. These expenditures— which amount to much more than the total National Drug Strategy funding—continue to be spent by governments. For example, private sector methadone maintenance treatment has been largely covered by Medicare Benefits Schedule funding while public hospital drug and alcohol services receive funding through the Medicare Agreements.

(b) Simple comparisons of drug strategy expenditure on a per capita basis made between Australia and the USA are unlikely to have any validity given the significant differences in health, social and economic infrastructure in our two countries. Nonetheless, I have asked my Department to investigate the levels of expenditure on drug issues in a number of different countries which are comparable with Australia and to advise me on this issue.
(4) I consider that it would be wasteful of resources and unnecessary to convene a national drug summit at this point in time, for two reasons.

Firstly, an independent evaluation of the National Drug Strategy has just been completed. The evaluation addressed the advisory and wider consultative mechanisms in place through the National Drug Strategy. The evaluation team, led by Professor Eric Single of the Department of Preventive Medicine and Biostatistics in the University of Toronto and Professor Tim Rohl of the Australian Graduate School of Police Management in Charles Sturt University, received written submissions and held discussions with expert researchers, service providers, community groups and consumer organisations. The report of the evaluation will be discussed by the Australasian Police Ministers' Council and the Australian Health Ministers' Conference at their respective meetings in July 1997. These meetings are expected to look at the future directions of the National Drug Strategy and particularly the incorporation of broader consultative mechanisms as recommended by the evaluators. If such a broad consultative approach can be achieved, a national drug summit will not be necessary.

Secondly, the "heroin problem" is complex and could not be resolved by a single summit. We need to develop and maintain a multi‐faceted, national, strategic approach, such as that being pursued through the Illicit Drugs Expert Working Group (a subcommittee of the National Drug Strategy Committee), in conjunction with ongoing public debate and consultation. This underlines the importance of a broad consultative mechanism within the framework of the National Drug Strategy.

(5) (a) On 2 April 1985, the Prime Minister, each State Premier and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory met in the House of Representatives chamber in Parliament House, Canberra. That meeting was the Special Premier's Conference on Drugs, later known as The Drugs Summit.

(b) The 1985 Drug Summit established the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse (NCADA), which subsequently became the National Drug Strategy. At that Special Premier's Conference, all States and Territories, and the Commonwealth committed themselves to conducting a continuing, co‐operative effort attacking drug abuse at all levels of Australian society.

(c) The Summit established the broad directions of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse. In particular, it was decided that the Campaign would place emphasis on reducing the demand for drugs through education, treatment and rehabilitation programs, while also including efforts to maintain and enhance restrictions on the supply of illegal drugs.

(6) (a) The first national study of HIV prevalence in injecting drug users carried out during 1989‐90 in Perth, Brisbane, Melbourne and Sydney reported a prevalence of approximately 7 per cent in Sydney and approximately 2 per cent in the other cities. Similar results were obtained when the survey was repeated in 1994, and in national surveys of HIV prevalence among people attending needle exchange programs in 1995 and 1996. The HIV prevalence overall was 2 per cent in 1995 and 1.7 per cent in 1996.

(b) In 1996 clients attending needle exchange programs were tested for hepatitis C (HCV) antibody. The overall prevalence of HCV was 66 per cent. There was a small non‐significant increase in HCV prevalence in 1996 compared to a similar survey in 1995 when a prevalence of 63 per cent was recorded. The highest seroprevalence rate was recorded in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory (81 per cent) and the lowest rate in Queensland (46 per cent). Clients who had been injecting for more than three years and who were over 35 years of age were more likely to be HCV positive.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: AusAID Dam Project Personnel in Indo-China

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say how many AusAID dam project personnel in Indo‐China have had a work history outside of dam construction activity or its ancillary engineering aspects.
(2) What measures have been taken to ensure a reasonable level of scrutiny of the social impacts of the projects on the local population.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government aid agency, AusAID, has no dam projects or dam project personnel in Indo‐China.
The only support that may be loosely interpreted in this way is our support to the Laos Hydropower Project Office through the United Nations Development Program (UNDP).

The Lao Government has identified hydropower as its primary resource to provide revenue to develop the country. The Laos Hydropower Project Office (HPO) has the responsibility of assessing commercial proposals to develop hydropower in Laos. The HPO lacks education, skills and experience to properly assess the hydropower proposals to ensure that the people of Laos receive a fair return from the utilisation of a major resource, and that all environmental, social, legal and technical concerns are met.

The UNDP approached AusAID and sought Australian participation in an assistance program aimed at upgrading the skills levels of HPO personnel and at establishing a system that will allow hydropower proposals to be properly assessed. AusAID is not the only donor assisting the HPO in this program.

Since August 1995 AusAID has been funding, through UNDP, a full time "Power Development Adviser" and a number of short term Advisers. All of these advisers have had relevant work history within the hydropower industry. This is to be expected given the nature of the tasks required.
The Long Term adviser assists the HPO to plan and manage the appropriate development of hydropower in Laos, taking account of all relevant environmental, social, legal and technical factors.
The AusAID funded short term advisers include a financial adviser and a costings engineer. Provision of a short term legal adviser and a full time "Environment Adviser" has recently been agreed.
Any advisers funded by AusAID have experience relevant to the Terms of Reference for which they are engaged.

(2) The Lao Government Hydropower Office, (HPO), is responsible for the scrutiny of social impacts of potential Projects on the local population. There has been concern regarding the HPO's capacity to assess all proposals. Hence the support AusAID is providing through UNDP is highly valued in Laos, and supports the Lao Government's efforts to ensure all environmental and social impacts of projects are fully considered.
